captions.text: You have known for a long time that the universe is expanding.
If you look at distant galaxies, they are moving away from us,
And the more distant galaxies are moving faster.
So really, it’s not really an explosion of galaxies away from us;
All galaxies are moving away from all the other galaxies.
Space itself is getting bigger.
But you would expect that the expansion of the universe is something that will slow down.
These galaxies have gravity and they attract each other
So you would expect that the expansion of the universe will diminish with time.
So it was a big surprise in 1998 when we realized that the galaxies were actually speeding up.
If you look at one galaxy, non-only it is moving away from us,
But tomorrow it will be moving away from us faster.
This is what we call the acceleration of the universe.
But we are not completely shocked,
We have a good theoretical model handed down to us
by Einstein.
The idea that even empty space has energy, what we call vacuum energy or dark energy.
And this vacuum energy pushes space itself and causes distant galaxies to move away from us
Faster and faster. That is where the acceleration comes from.
So theoretical cosmologists are trying to understand what could be going on.
Is it really vacuum energy? Is some variation of that?
Or is it even a modification of Einstein’s general relativity, our theory of gravity?
If vacuum energy is the right answer, the universe will continue to expand,
The galaxies will move away from us and the universe will gradually become a lonelier, darker,
emptier place.

title: 2011 Nobel Prize: Dark Energy feat. Sean Carroll

comments.author: Sanguine M

comments.text:
I've always been confused by this: Why do we not just call it Antigravity? 
 If gravity is the attractive force between mass, with the higher the mass 
the stronger the gravity, why would it be outside the box to think that the 
flip side of that coin is that the more rarefied the vacuum, the the 
stronger the antigravity?  There would surely be an equilibrium point where 
the distance between any two massive objects balances the gravity and 
antigravity (or gravitational attraction and "dark energy" repulsion), but 
the force of the initial expansion of the singularity at the Big Bang 
imparted enough momentum to overcome that equilibrium and antigravity got a 
boost.  Now the further any two objects (like galaxies) are, the stronger 
the antigravity (for the same reason the closer the two objects are the 
stronger the normal gravity) making them "fall" apart faster and faster.

Am I missing something fundamental?﻿
comments.author: MrARock001

comments.text:
What if dark energy doesn't really exist and the universe only seems to 
expand faster than light should. As in, what if instead of dark energy 
there is a "bubble" of sorts that has the width of the extra space that 
exists that doesn't account for the observable universe (about a radius of 
30 billion light-years), but has the density of a black hole evenly 
everywhere with the universe having a fixed size? If that were the case, 
then the "bubble" would be so uniformly dense that light would not be able 
to pass through it. However that would effectively stop light, which is 
impossible because the speed of light is a constant and so the only 
possibility would be for light to quantum-tunnel from the outside of the 
"bubble" to the inside, and this process just takes light more time to get 
to us, (as in the extra 30 billion light-years that we can't see yet). As 
light wouldn't actually get to the "bubble" and simply passes to the other 
side, then the "bubble" couldn't actually be seen since light wouldn't 
reflect it, which is why we can see no evidence of such a phenomenon.  And 
the bubble slowly degrades into entropy with the edge being the energy that 
is being expended, which is why it takes light less time then to reach us 
and why we think that space is expanding when in reality, it is simply 
reaching us faster because space is actually shrinking, (or at least the 
space in the hypothetical "bubble"). In fact, this could be the process 
that occurs in every black hole, effectively creating it's own universe 
that one would think too small to exist, however it expands in itself, just 
as our universe is theorized to be doing.

I realize that this is a pretty long comment, but I would appreciate any 
feedback as to why or why not this theory could actually be plausible. :)﻿

comments.author: Catherine Jackson

comments.text:
This might sound naive, but I believe there could be a more straightforward 
reason why more distant galaxies seem to be moving away faster.
The further away an astronomical object is, the older the light that 
arrives is (ie: the light from something four billion lightyears away took 
four billion years to arrive).
So maybe what we're seeing is how fast they were going when the light from 
these objects left, not how fast they are going when the light arrives here?
The further away objects would naturally appear to be traveling faster, as 
when the light we are receiving now was emitted is further into the past 
and thus closer to the big bang.
The whole "things get faster the further away they are" could be an optical 
illusion, caused by the speed of light.﻿

comments.author: Lumisatmi

comments.text:
It may seem like a naive question, but those are often the best ones. There 
are several different yardsticks they use, which tend to back each other 
up. They have redshift, they have type 1-A supernova, they have (forget the 
tag) the spatial relationship between galaxies... If there was a systemic 
distortion as you describe, which is a very good and valid point, then the 
different measuring systems would have shown it up. The figures obtained 
from differing systems would not support each other.
comments.author: Kneedragon1962

comments.text:
No. Today we see the light they emitted four billion years ago, for 
example. Tomorrow we see the light they emitted four billion minus one 
years ago. We see that in that day, the galaxy has moved away further. We 
can observe this effect in objects just one light year away as well as 10 
billion light years away. We also have redshift, which we can also observe 
in objects near to us, such as comets in the Oort cloud. So no, it's not an 
optical illusion.

the galaxies together.

the dark matter in both galaxies that attracts each other. Of course, the 
rest has an effect too, but not that significant.

comments.text:
Dr. Isen explains to Bane about ethereal paths across the universe and 
neutrino runways from the big bang. Want to know more?
  Check out my new novel Manner of the Sundog, a geopolitical Sci-Fi 
thriller about a young physicist living in a postmodern Antarctica. The 
story portrays life, culture and the political struggles following a 
century of intense climate change, war and social discord. Young physics 
prodigy, Bane Elrick, is thrown into a conflict between the Annortic's 
governing body, ICS, and an imperialistic union controlled by GRANT corp. 
an aggressive multinational resource and trade company. The story is set 
around the city of Ellsworth, located on the beautiful west coast of 
Antarctica, where ICS has become the target of espionage and the victim of 
brutal attacks carried out by Grant's Lynx army in an attempt to recover 
land rights and lost secrets of intangible technological powers. Bane 
Elrick tells his story of life, love, and excessive greed, and his rise to 
leadership of the world’s most elusive continent and sovereign 
nation…Antarctica. ﻿

comments.text:
Want the Answer? Space is just another form of Energy wich is affected by 
gravity. EXPANDING SPACE is a misconception, and this is why:
Imagine Space being some gas in a balloon and you are inside of it. to get 
from point A to point B, u need to travel through X space. Now imagine the 
balloon gets smaller (gravity forces the "space-gas" to shrink). Now, to 
get from A to B you need to travel through more space, because there is 
more space collected together. (To understand this, you mustn´t think the 
distance between A and B as two different spots in space, but really just a 
length in a room without space or energy) Now it looks you need longer to 
travel from A to B, but, in fact, you are just moving through more space. 
The same goes for light in space, wich leads to the idea of expanding 
space. => No "vacuum energy", "dark energy" etc. , just Space as another 
form of energy﻿

comments.author: ThePyromaniac

comments.text:
Einstein's vacuum energy wasn't the same as the vacuum energy we are 
talking about.

Einstein proposed this kind of energy as a mechanism by which the Universe 
could be in a steady state, not expanding nor contracting.  His earlier 
theories had a problem in that, they predicted that space must either be 
expanding or contracting, and it could never be something in between.

This was used to support Steady State Theory, which was the original way 
scientists tried to avoid the "God" question.  Physicists don't like 
beginnings, because it implies that even physical reality must have had a 
cause.  If physical reality had a cause, then Naturalism is false, and many 
scientists subscribe to Naturalism.

Scientists, unable to avoid the prospect of a beginning of time, now try to 
attack philosophy by saying that quantum mechanics defy the laws of logic, 
and thus they can say anything they want.  ﻿
comments.author: Global Warming Skeptic

comments.text: In no way does the Big Bang theory negate materialism nor naturalism.

comments.text:
All of the galaxies in our local cluster of galaxies are gravitationally 
locked. The galaxies in our local cluster of galaxies are not far from each 
other relative to the entire universe and so they are just as 
gravitationally locked to each other as the moon is gravitationally locked 
to earth. This is why the Andromeda galaxy is moving towards our own 
galaxy. It is the space between the clusters that are really expanding. I 
hope this helped and if anyone has any corrections or additions to my 
comment please do so so I can learn as well. Cheers!

comments.author: fourPOdimethylT

comments.text:
+Ranstead Moons That is only a theory. There is no definitive as to what 
dark energy actually is, however it is more than likely that it is in fact 
a form of energy, as it acts as a force. Even if the theory you've 
presented is true, those quantum fluctuations are still energy, and the 
expansive result is energy driven. 

That theory is often liked because it explains an incomprehensible 
phenomenon in a way that makes sense based on our current understanding of 
physics, however, one may fail to admit that our current understanding of 
physics is far from complete. Dark matter, for instance, cannot be so 
easily explained, yet it makes up the second largest portion of our 
universe. It could be that there are energetic fields that are simply 
beyond our technological level of perception, and they will remain elusive, 
but only for the time being.
comments.author: fourPOdimethylT

comments.text:
+fourPOdimethylT Dark energy itself isn't *really* a form of energy, it's 
just the behaviour of already existing particles as far as I learned it... 
Dark energy is the force provided by particles randomly popping into 
existence through quantum fluctuations, these particles cause an outwards 
'push' on anything around it, and if this 'push' is greater in one region 
of space than another, it can be used to push real objects through space...

That's how I understood it, but it's not a perfect understanding haha, I 
still find it really confusing
comments.author: Ranstead Moons

comments.text:
Not quite. Dark energy is (so they think as of now) a real form of energy, 
made up of subatomic particles, just like dark matter. Except instead of 
nearly invisible matter, it's nearly invisible energy. A vacuum wouldn't be 
able to push everything away from each other; for massive galaxies, 
galactic clusters, etc. to be pushed away from each other, energy is 
required. So it is energy, we call it dark because it's nearly undetectable 
by us.
comments.author: fourPOdimethylT

comments.text:
The current value of lambda (cosmological constant) associated with the 
vacuum energy (and its negative pressure and expectation value) that 
theoretical cosmologists feel is responsible for the universe's 
acceleration of expansion is off by an order of magnitude larger than any 
other 'predictive' value in science. 

We need a modified theory of gravity. John Moffat discusses this in his 
book "Reinventing Gravity" if anyone cares to learn alternate theories that 
have much stronger explanations for the acceleration of the universe than 
what Mr. Carroll has offered here. (Mr. Carroll's explanation has its basis 
in Einstein's general relativity and the observation of Type 1a supernovae 
being significantly more redshifted than they 'should be' - however, he DID 
mention an alternate theory of gravity being something to consider, which 
is more than most physicists today would entertain).﻿

comments.author: Terry David Silvercloud

comments.text:
It's all rather basic physics.  It could be shown in a sound demonstration 
but would require a rather large set up... perhaps 110 square miles of 
sound tubing... any large tube that could be bent.  You would then compare 
sounds coming from different distance so see if you get doppler affect.  
Just think about it... it's all rather simple.  You have to go from A to B 
but you aren't allowed to take the shortest distance.  This happens for 
every single star you encounter, or gas cloud, or charged field... for 
billions of light years of travel.  For every step forward you take 1/8th 
step (example) backwards.  Now add up those hundreds of thousands of zigz 
and zags.  And remember... when you finally get the light signal, it was 
not the one aimed where you were billions of years ago... but where you are 
now.  You are nowhere near where you were in space 15 billion years ago.  
In fact, you move billions of miles every year just turning around the 
Milky Way... and it's nowhere near where it was when you FINALLY get the 
light signature.  If the more distant ones seem shifted, small wonder... 
and some of the blue frequecies may not have made it at all.
comments.author: Terry David Silvercloud

comments.text:
+Terry David Silvercloud How can you prove that it zig zags and not 
redshifts?
comments.author: Deliciousbutter

comments.text:
I'm not well asshole.  But I'll get around to it.  Red shift is also caused 
by the fact that light bends towards stars... and galaxies, and the fact 
that space has clouds of hydrogen.  The point is, light zig zags it's way 
to us.  And the number of zigs and zags increases exponentially.  You may 
want to look that word up.  The point is, there is a point in exponential 
limits where you reach your observable 'edge of the universe'.  Lights from 
the most distant galaxies may travel 10 times the distance to get here vs a 
straight line and that can cause doppler affect and you will interpret that 
as red shift.  Sorry... no expansion.
